cats.safety_description: Acai is safe for cats to eat in small quantities, but it is not a necessary part of their diet. It is high in antioxidants which can be beneficial for their immune system. Acai also contains some B vitamins, vitamin C, calcium, and iron.
cats.guidance: Although acai can provide some benefits, it should be given sparingly as a treat, and not make up a significant part of their diet.

dogs.safety_description: Acai is safe for dogs to eat in small quantities. It is high in antioxidants which can be beneficial for their immune system. Acai also contains some B vitamins, vitamin C, calcium, and iron.
dogs.guidance: Although acai can provide some benefits, it should be given sparingly as a treat, and not make up a significant part of their diet.

cats.safety_description: Acorn squash is safe for cats to eat in moderate amounts. It is high in fiber, vitamin A, and potassium, which can aid digestion and maintain healthy bones and muscles.
cats.guidance: Acorn squash can be a healthy addition to their diet, and can be given as a treat. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

dogs.safety_description: Acorn squash is safe for dogs to eat in moderate amounts. It is low in calories and fat, and high in fiber, vitamin A, and potassium, which can aid digestion and maintain healthy bones and muscles.
dogs.guidance: Acorn squash can be a healthy addition to their diet, and can be given as a treat. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

cats.safety_description: Alfalfa sprouts are safe for cats to eat. They are a good source of protein, fiber, vitamin C, and some minerals.
cats.guidance: Alfalfa sprouts can be a healthy addition to their diet when fed in moderation. They can be given as a treat or mixed into their food. However, they should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

dogs.safety_description: Alfalfa sprouts are safe for dogs to eat. They are a good source of protein, fiber, vitamin C, and some minerals.
dogs.guidance: Alfalfa sprouts can be a healthy addition to their diet when fed in moderation. They can be given as a treat or mixed into their food. However, they should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

cats.safety_description: Almonds are not recommended for cats, as they can lead to intestinal upset and even blockages. Almonds are high in fat, which can lead to obesity and other health problems.
cats.guidance: Almonds should not be fed to cats, as they have no nutritional value for them and are not necessary for their diet.

dogs.safety_description: Almonds are safe for dogs to eat in moderation, but they are high in fat and calories. Too many almonds can lead to weight gain and other health problems. However, they are a good source of protein, fiber, healthy fats, vitamin E, and magnesium.
dogs.guidance: Almonds can be given to dogs as a treat, but not more than 1-2 almonds per day depending of the dog size. They should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

cats.safety_description: Almond butter is safe for cats to eat in small amounts as a treat. It is high in fat and calories, which can lead to obesity and other health problems. However, it is a good source of protein, fiber, healthy fats, and some vitamins and minerals.
cats.guidance: Almond butter should be given very sparingly to cats as a treat, and no more than a small lick on a fingertip. It should not make up a significant part of their diet.

dogs.safety_description: Almond butter is safe for dogs to eat in small amounts as a treat. It is high in fat and calories, which can lead to obesity and other health problems. However, it is a good source of protein, fiber, healthy fats, and some vitamins and minerals.
dogs.guidance: Almond butter can be given to dogs as a treat, but not more than a teaspoon a day depending of the dog size. It should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

dogs.safety_description: Irish stew is safe for dogs to eat in moderation, as it can contain lean meat and vegetables that provide some nutritional value.

cats.guidance: Sweet potato can be included in their diet in small amounts. It should be cooked and mashed or pureed before serving. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

dogs.safety_description: Sweet potato is safe for dogs to eat in moderation, as it is a good source of fiber and some vitamins and minerals.
dogs.guidance: Sweet potato can be included in their diet as a healthy and nutritious ingredient. It can be served cooked or raw. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

cats.safety_description: Tuna is safe for cats to eat in small amounts, as it is a good source of protein and some vitamins and minerals. However, it should be served sparingly and should never be the sole source of a cat's diet, as it can lead to deficiencies.
cats.guidance: Tuna can be included in their diet in small amounts. It should be cooked and served fresh or canned in water, not oil. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

dogs.safety_description: Tuna is safe for dogs to eat in moderation, as it is a good source of protein and some vitamins and minerals. However, it should be served sparingly and should never be the sole source of a dog's diet, as it can lead to deficiencies.
dogs.guidance: Tuna can be included in their diet in small amounts. It should be cooked and served fresh or canned in water, not oil. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

cats.safety_description: Turkey is safe for cats to eat in moderation. It is a good source of protein and some vitamins and minerals.
cats.guidance: Turkey can be included in their diet in small amounts. It should be cooked and served boneless to avoid any risk of choking or injury. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

dogs.safety_description: Turkey is safe for dogs to eat in moderation. It is a good source of protein and some vitamins and minerals.
dogs.guidance: Turkey can be included in their diet in small amounts. It should be cooked and served boneless to avoid any risk of choking or injury. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

cats.safety_description: Tomatoes are safe for cats to eat in small amounts. However, they should be cooked or pureed to break down the toxic enzyme solanine, which can cause gastrointestinal upset and nervous system depression.
cats.guidance: Tomatoes can be included in their diet in small amounts. They should be cooked and pureed before serving. However, they should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

dogs.safety_description: Tomatoes are safe for dogs to eat in small amounts. However, they should be cooked or pureed to break down the toxic enzyme solanine, which can cause gastrointestinal upset and nervous system depression.
dogs.guidance: Tomatoes can be included in their diet as an occasional treat. They should be cooked and pureed before serving. However, they should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

cats.safety_description: Watermelon is safe for cats to eat in small amounts. It is a good source of vitamins and antioxidants but is high in natural sugars.
cats.guidance: Watermelon can be given to cats as a refreshing treat on occasion. The rind and seeds should be removed, and the fruit should be chopped into small pieces before serving. However, they should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

dogs.safety_description: Watermelon is safe for dogs to eat in small amounts. It is a good source of vitamins and antioxidants but is high in natural sugars.
dogs.guidance: Watermelon can be given to dogs as a refreshing treat on occasion. The rind and seeds should be removed, and the fruit should be chopped into small pieces before serving. However, they should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

cats.safety_description: Whitefish is safe for cats to eat in moderation. It is a good source of protein and omega-3 fatty acids.
cats.guidance: Whitefish can be included in their diet in small amounts. However, it should be served sparingly and should never be the sole source of their diet, as it can lead to deficiencies. It should be cooked and served boneless to avoid any risk of choking or injury. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

dogs.safety_description: Whitefish is safe for dogs to eat in moderation. It is a good source of protein and omega-3 fatty acids.
dogs.guidance: Whitefish can be included in their diet in small amounts. However, it should be served sparingly and should never be the sole source of their diet, as it can lead to deficiencies. It should be cooked and served boneless to avoid any risk of choking or injury. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

cats.safety_description: Wild rice is safe for cats to eat in small amounts. It is a good source of fiber and some vitamins and minerals.
cats.guidance: Wild rice can be included in their diet in small amounts. It should be plain and unsalted. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

dogs.safety_description: Wild rice is safe for dogs to eat in moderation. It is a good source of fiber and some vitamins and minerals.
dogs.guidance: Wild rice can be included in their diet in small amounts. It should be plain and unsalted. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

cats.safety_description: Plain, unsweetened yogurt is safe for cats to eat in small amounts, as it is a good source of protein and calcium.
cats.guidance: Yogurt can be included in their diet in small amounts. However, cats may be lactose intolerant, so it is important to monitor for any signs of gastrointestinal upset. It should be plain and unsweetened, preferably organic and without any additives or artificial preservatives. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

dogs.safety_description: Plain, unsweetened yogurt is safe for dogs to eat in moderation, as it is a good source of protein and calcium.
dogs.guidance: Yogurt can be included in their diet as an occasional treat. Dogs may be lactose intolerant, so it is important to monitor for any signs of gastrointestinal upset. It should be plain and unsweetened, preferably organic and without any additives or artificial preservatives. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

cats.safety_description: Yellow squash is safe for cats to eat in small amounts. It is a good source of vitamins and fiber.
cats.guidance: Yellow squash can be included in their diet as a healthy and nutritious ingredient. It should be cooked and mashed or pureed before serving. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

dogs.safety_description: Yellow squash is safe for dogs to eat in moderation. It is a good source of vitamins and fiber.
dogs.guidance: Yellow squash can be included in their diet as a healthy and nutritious ingredient. It can be served cooked or raw, sliced or diced. However, it should not make up more than 10% of their daily food intake.

cats.safety_description: Alcohol can cause vomiting, diarrhea, decreased coordination, central nervous system depression, difficulty breathing, tremors, abnormal blood acidity, coma, and even death in pets.
cats.guidance: Alcohol is highly toxic to cats and should never be given to them under any circumstances.

dogs.safety_description: Alcohol can cause vomiting, diarrhea, decreased coordination, central nervous system depression, difficulty breathing, tremors, abnormal blood acidity, coma, and even death in pets.
dogs.guidance: Alcohol is highly toxic to dogs and should never be given to them under any circumstances.

cats.safety_description: Avocado contains persin, which can cause vomiting, diarrhea, and fluid accumulation in the chest, abdomen, and heart in pets.
cats.guidance: Avocado should not be given to cats as it may cause digestive upset, breathing difficulties, heart problems, and even death.

dogs.safety_description: Avocado contains persin, which can cause vomiting, diarrhea, and fluid accumulation in the chest, abdomen, and heart in pets.
dogs.guidance: While small amounts of avocado flesh are generally safe for dogs, the pit, skin, and leaves contain persin, which can lead to vomiting, diarrhea, and respiratory distress if ingested. It's best to avoid feeding avocado to dogs altogether.

cats.safety_description: Chocolate contains theobromine and caffeine, which can cause vomiting, diarrhea, increased thirst, panting, restlessness, increased heart rate, muscle tremors, seizures, and even death in pets.
cats.guidance: Chocolate should never be given to cats as even a small amount can lead to serious health problems.

dogs.safety_description: Chocolate contains theobromine and caffeine, which can cause vomiting, diarrhea, increased thirst, panting, restlessness, increased heart rate, muscle tremors, seizures, and even death in pets.
dogs.guidance: Chocolate is highly toxic to dogs, with darker chocolate and unsweetened baking chocolate containing higher levels of theobromine. Signs of chocolate poisoning in dogs may include vomiting, diarrhea, restlessness, tremors, seizures, and an irregular heartbeat. Seek veterinary attention right away if you suspect your dog has ingested chocolate.

cats.safety_description: Garlic can damage red blood cells and cause anemia in pets. Symptoms may include weakness, lethargy, loss of appetite, pale gums, and even collapse or death.
cats.guidance: Garlic should not be given to cats in any amount.

dogs.safety_description: Garlic can damage red blood cells and cause anemia in pets. Symptoms may include weakness, lethargy, loss of appetite, pale gums, and even collapse or death.
dogs.guidance: While small amounts of garlic are generally safe for dogs, larger doses can lead to health problems. Signs of garlic poisoning in dogs may include vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, weakness, loss of appetite, pale gums, and an elevated heart rate. If your dog has ingested garlic, contact your veterinarian for advice.

cats.safety_description: Onions can damage red blood cells and cause anemia in pets. Symptoms may include weakness, lethargy, loss of appetite, pale gums, and even collapse or death.
cats.guidance: Onions should not be given to cats in any amount.

dogs.safety_description: Onions can damage red blood cells and cause anemia in pets. Symptoms may include weakness, lethargy, loss of appetite, pale gums, and even collapse or death.
dogs.guidance: While small amounts of onions are generally safe for dogs, larger doses can lead to health problems. Signs of onion poisoning in dogs may include vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, weakness, loss of appetite, pale gums, and an elevated heart rate. If your dog has ingested onions, contact your veterinarian for advice.

cats.safety_description: Xylitol is a sugar substitute commonly found in chewing gum, candy, baked goods, and other products. It can cause insulin release, leading to hypoglycemia (low blood sugar), seizures, liver failure, and even death in pets.
cats.guidance: Xylitol should never be given to cats, and cats should not be allowed access to any products containing xylitol.

dogs.safety_description: Xylitol is a sugar substitute commonly found in chewing gum, candy, baked goods, and other products. It can cause insulin release, leading to hypoglycemia (low blood sugar), seizures, liver failure, and even death in pets.
dogs.guidance: Xylitol is highly toxic to dogs in even small amounts. Signs of xylitol poisoning in dogs may include vomiting, loss of coordination, seizures, and liver failure. Contact your veterinarian immediately if you suspect your dog has ingested xylitol, even if you don't see any symptoms right away.

cats.safety_description: Grapes and raisins can cause kidney failure in pets, with symptoms including vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, and decreased appetite.
cats.guidance: Grapes and raisins should not be given to cats as they can cause serious kidney problems.

dogs.safety_description: Grapes and raisins can cause kidney failure in pets, with symptoms including vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, and decreased appetite.
dogs.guidance: Grapes and raisins are highly toxic to dogs and can cause kidney failure, with symptoms including vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, and decreased appetite. Contact your veterinarian immediately if you suspect your dog has ingested grapes or raisins.

cats.safety_description: Macadamia nuts can cause lethargy, vomiting, hyperthermia (elevated body temperature), tremors, and possible neurological effects in pets.
cats.guidance: Macadamia nuts should not be given to cats as they can cause serious health problems.

dogs.safety_description: Macadamia nuts can cause lethargy, vomiting, hyperthermia (elevated body temperature), tremors, and possible neurological effects in pets.
dogs.guidance: Macadamia nuts are highly toxic to dogs and can cause symptoms including lethargy, vomiting, hyperthermia (elevated body temperature), tremors, and possible neurological effects. Contact your veterinarian immediately if you suspect your dog has ingested macadamia nuts.

cats.safety_description: Raw meat and eggs can contain bacteria such as Salmonella and E. coli, which can cause gastrointestinal problems in pets.
cats.guidance: Raw meat and eggs should not be given to cats as they may contain harmful bacteria that can make them sick.

dogs.safety_description: Raw meat and eggs can contain bacteria such as Salmonella and E. coli, which can cause gastrointestinal problems in pets.
dogs.guidance: Raw meat and eggs should be avoided for dogs to reduce the risk of bacterial contamination. Always cook meat and eggs thoroughly before feeding them to your dog.

cats.safety_description: Antifreeze contains ethylene glycol, which can be fatal to pets even in small amounts. Symptoms may include vomiting, diarrhea, loss of coordination, seizures, kidney failure, and even death.
cats.guidance: Antifreeze should be kept out of reach of pets and spills should be cleaned up immediately. If you suspect your cat has ingested antifreeze, seek veterinary attention right away.

dogs.safety_description: Antifreeze contains ethylene glycol, which can be fatal to pets even in small amounts. Symptoms may include vomiting, diarrhea, loss of coordination, seizures, kidney failure, and even death.
dogs.guidance: Antifreeze should be kept out of reach of pets and spills should be cleaned up immediately. If you suspect your dog has ingested antifreeze, seek veterinary attention right away.

cats.safety_description: Many household cleaners contain chemicals that can be toxic to pets, especially if ingested. Symptoms may include vomiting, diarrhea, drooling, difficulty breathing, and even death in severe cases.
cats.guidance: Household cleaners should be kept out of reach of pets, and surfaces should be thoroughly cleaned and dried before allowing pets back into an area. If your cat has ingested a household cleaner, contact your veterinarian or a poison control center immediately.

dogs.safety_description: Many household cleaners contain chemicals that can be toxic to pets, especially if ingested. Symptoms may include vomiting, diarrhea, drooling, difficulty breathing, and even death in severe cases.
dogs.guidance: Household cleaners should be kept out of reach of pets, and surfaces should be thoroughly cleaned and dried before allowing pets back into an area. If your dog has ingested a household cleaner, contact your veterinarian or a poison control center immediately.

cats.safety_description: Many human medications, including over-the-counter pain relievers, can be toxic to cats if ingested. Symptoms may include vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, loss of appetite, and even death.
cats.guidance: Never give your cat medication intended for humans, and keep all medications out of reach of pets. If your cat has ingested a medication, contact your veterinarian or a poison control center immediately.

dogs.safety_description: Many human medications, including over-the-counter pain relievers, can be toxic to dogs if ingested. Symptoms may include vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, loss of appetite, and even death.
dogs.guidance: Never give your dog medication intended for humans, and keep all medications out of reach of pets. If your dog has ingested a medication, contact your veterinarian or a poison control center immediately.

cats.safety_description: Many types of lilies, including Easter lilies, tiger lilies, and Asiatic lilies, can be toxic to cats if ingested. Symptoms may include vomiting, loss of appetite, lethargy, and kidney failure.
cats.guidance: Keep all lilies out of reach of cats, and seek veterinary attention immediately if your cat has ingested any part of a lily plant.

dogs.safety_description: While lilies are not toxic to dogs, ingestion can lead to gastrointestinal upset.
dogs.guidance: It's still best to keep lilies out of reach of dogs to avoid them ingesting any part of the plant.
